intro: Epicampes coerulea, commonly known as the bluebells of the Andes, is a flowering plant native to the high-altitude regions of South America. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its striking blue or violet bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, thriving in cool and moist conditions. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered in fine hairs, while its stems are erect and sturdy. Epicampes coerulea is valued for its ornamental beauty and is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
